seg.seg: ... (and say to him (?):) «To a (hard-)to-reach place you must go, because: || In the [tune] meneklinaṃ || You are able to speak, ... the way ...
... The royal command [and] the respect for [your] father you treat with contempt. You must go
Den königlichen Befehl, das väterliche Wohlwollen verspottest du.
The royal command, [your] father's good-will you deride.
(to your death (?) for this.)» ... When the mother of the Bodhisattva, the queen, saw [her] son (with) [his] beautiful body like Indra’s thunderbolt ...
..., she, intending to say «O merciful one!», fainted [and] (fell) to the ground.
... (Wie sie den von den Caṇḍālas weggeführten Sohn(?)) sah, wurde sie, als sie. "O Mitleidiger!" sagen wollte, ohnmächtig [und] (fiel) zur Erde.
... (When she) saw ([her] son led away by the Caṇḍālas) she fainted as she wanted to say "Oh compassionate one!" [and] (fell) to the ground.
... (Having come round again (?)), embracing the feet of king Brahmadatta like a liana, she says: || In the [tune] vi(śikkonaṃ ||)
«... Remember! Because of desire for a son you have made offerings to the gods for a long time.
Erinnere dich: Den Göttern hast du im Verlangen nach einem Sohn (lange) Opfer dargebracht.
Remember: Desiring a son, (long) you [have?] offered sacrifices to the gods.
... If he is really abandoned by you, fulfill my wish [that] the Caṇḍālas will kill me first.
If he is really given up by you, fulfil my wish [that] the caṇḍālas will first kill me. (cf 19)
(1.)» ... Thereupon the queen, finding no favour [lit. being without affection], (says, clasping (?)) [her] fettered son with [her] whole body
... : « ... face ... will perish before long, killed by the sword. In dreams the comparison
… human birth … before long he will perish, killed by the sword. (cf 19)
... close. Completely in vain did you come in response to [our] great wishes to please our hearts.
... because of [his] Bodhisattva-like consideration, as if without suffering in spite of [lit. even by] [his] mother’s suffering, he (remained) without speaking.
... [But] looking affectionately, as it were, with [his] blue-coloured eyes at the people of the city, he thinks:

meneklinaṃ: This tune has 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7.
Sieg's restoration cämpamo träṅktsi y(n)e(ś naṣt) '[Obwohl] (du) augenscheinlich imstande (bist) zu sprechen' (18) is not possible: the reading y(n)e is excluded.

(b)odhisatvāp mācar lāts 'the mother of the Bodhisattva, the queen' is probably the subject of the abs. pälkoräṣ 'having seen'. This would mean that wlāññäktes wājärr oki kräntsonāṃ kapśi(ñño) and another ca. 18 syllables all belong to the object of pälkoräṣ, which probably ends with s(e) 'son'. 19 fills in the end of this lacuna as "(Wie sie den von den Caṇḍālas weggeführten Sohn (?)) sah". Indeed, it is likely that the queen sees her son in need, but the precise restoration remains uncertain.
The line originally began with the last 5 syllables of the strophe. The following is again in prose.
vi(śikkonaṃ): This tune has 4x18 syllables, rhythm 7/7/4.
nuk: A writing error for ñuk.
In the preceding lacuna the king has probably refused her request.
(ak)m(a)l: So to be read against 19, who restores (oñi c)m(o)l 'human birth'; both c and o are excluded.

According to 19, these lines contain a strophe with a metre of 4x15 syllables. This is impossible because in b4 we have 19 syllables without punctuation (which Sieg expects after kenn ats) and because the caesurae are wrong (both ṣäpnasaṃ menā(k) and śāwaṃ ākālntwā kakmu should rather have been 4 + 3, see ). We should also note that Sieg's metrical analysis does not square with his translation.
